iv
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 6 Filed 11/21/25 Page 7 of 19
STATEMENT OF JURISDICTION
Under 28 U.S.C. § 158(a)(1), district courts have jurisdiction over appeals from
final judgments, orders and decrees of bankruptcy courts. An order reclassifying a
creditor’s claim as a general unsecured claim, instead of a non-dischargeable,
domestic support obligation, is a final judgment because it conclusively resolves a
separate dispute of the creditor’s claim or priority, such that no further litigation
involving the creditor is necessary. The Eleventh Circuit has held:
A final decision is generally ‘one which ends the litigation
on the merits and leaves nothing for the court to do but
execute the judgment.’ In bankruptcy proceedings, it is
generally the particular adversary proceeding or
controversy that must have been finally resolved, rather
than the entire bankruptcy litigation. Although courts ‘take
a more liberal view of what constitutes a separate dispute
for purposes of appeal’ in bankruptcy cases, the separate
dispute being assessed must have been finally resolved and
have nothing more for the bankruptcy court to do.
In re Charter Co., 778 F.2d 617, 621 (11th Cir.1985) (Citations omitted).
1
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 6 Filed 11/21/25 Page 8 of 19
STATEMENT OF THE ISSUES PRESENTED FOR REVIEW
I. The bankruptcy court erred to reversal by classifying
Creditor’s Claim Number 19 as a general unsecured
claim because the debt to the Creditor is a non-
dischargeable, domestic support obligation.
II. Changes made by BAPCPA further support finding the
divorce court’s equitable distribution of assets a non-
dischargeable, domestic support obligation.
STATEMENT OF THE CASE
Course of Proceedings Below
On September 20, 2024, Debtor filed his Chapter 13 Voluntary Petition in the
United States Bankruptcy Court for the Middle District of Alabama, Eatern Division.
Doc. 1. On December 2, 2024, Creditor filed her Proof of Claim asserting that Debtor
owed her $30,000. Claim 19-1. Creditor’s claim was assigned Claim Number 19.
Creditor’s Proof of Claim was subsequently amended to a claim for $32,000. Claim
19-2.
On December 10, 2024, Debtor objected to Creditor’s claim. Doc. 25. On
January 21, 2025, Creditor responded to Debtor’s Objection. Doc. 34. The parties
filed their Joint Stipulation on March 14, 2025. Doc. 48. On March 17, 2025, Debtor
withdrew his objection to Creditor’s Claim Number 19. Doc. 49. Debtor re-filed his
2
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 6 Filed 11/21/25 Page 9 of 19
objection to Creditor’s Claim Number 19 on March 28, 2025. Doc. 51. Creditor
responded to Debtor’s objection on March 31, 2025. Doc. 52.
On July 16, 2025, the Bankruptcy Court held an evidentiary hearing at which
the Debtor and Creditor testified. Doc. 103.
On September 5, 2025, the Bankruptcy Court issued its Order reclassifying
Creditor’s Claim Number 19 as a general unsecured claim. Doc. 73.
On September 8, 2025, Creditor filed her Notice of Appeal. Doc. 77. On
September 19, 2025, Creditor designated the record on appeal and ordered the
transcript of the July 16, 2025, evidentiary hearing on September 22, 23025. Doc. 84,
87.
On October 2, 2025, the Bankruptcy Court confirmed Debtor’s Chapter 13
Plan. The record on appeal was transmitted to this Court on October 15, 2025. Doc.
104.
Statement of Facts
1. On February 27, 2024, Creditor (or “Former Wife”) and Debtor (or
“Former Husband”) were divorced following a trial before the Tallapoosa Circuit
Court (Alexander City Division) by the entry of a Final Decree of Divorce. See
Exhibit 1 to Doc. 52.
3
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 6 Filed 11/21/25 Page 10 of 19
2. The Final Decree of Divorce ordered Debtor to pay to Creditor one-half
of the equity in the marital residence which is fifty-one thousand, four hundred eleven
dollars and 21/100 ($51,411.21). Said amount was ordered to be paid as follows:
$10,000.00 within 10 days of the entry of the Final Decree of Divorce, followed by
monthly payments of $2,000.00 per month for 21 consecutive months beginning April
1, 2024.1 See Exhibit 1 to Doc. 52.
3. Neither party was ordered to pay alimony. Id.
4. The Child Support Guidelines Form filed in the parties’ divorce action
[Form CS-42] shows a wide disparity between the parties’ monthly incomes with the
Debtor receiving $8,870 per month and the Creditor receiving $1,733 per month. R.
16, Creditor’s Ex. 2.The Final Decree of Divorce awarded primary physical custody
of the Parties’ Minor Children to the Former Husband and ordered the Former Wife
to pay child support to the Former Husband of $617 per month. R. 15, Creditor’s Ex.
1.
5. Debtor made payments to Creditor totaling $20,000.00 before filing his
Chapter 13 Petition on September 20, 2024, leaving a balance owing of $32,000.00.
Doc. 48, ¶ 5.
1 The Final Decree of Divorce further indicated that if the Former Husband paid
the full $51,411.21 within 90 days, he could avoid having to pay a total of $52,000,
otherwise the amount owing would be $52,000. R. 15, Creditor’s Ex. 1.
4
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 6 Filed 11/21/25 Page 11 of 19
6. Creditor testified that she needs the $2,000 payments ordered in the
divorce decree to meet her monthly financial obligations. R. 17. Creditor further
testified that she cannot meet her monthly financial obligations on her monthly
income of $1,733. R. 17-18. Creditor testified that she understood that the 21 monthly
payments of $2,000 to her ordered by the divorce court were to be for her support. R.
18.
SUMMARY OF ARGUMENT
A domestic support obligation is non-dischargeable in bankruptcy. The
decision whether the Debtor’s payment obligation is dischargeable or non-
dischargeable does not hinge on whether it is a property settlement or alimony. A
property settlement can be a non-dischargeable domestic support obligation if it
achieves the same goals as a support obligation. The statutory language requires the
court to determine whether the obligation is in the nature of a support obligation. A
critical factor in making this determination is whether there is a wide disparity
between the parties’ incomes. In this case, Debtor’s monthly income is more than five
times greater than Creditor’s monthly income.
In a case with very similar facts, not addressed by the Court below, this Court
reversed the bankruptcy court’s determination that Debtor’s obligation was a non-
5
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 6 Filed 11/21/25 Page 12 of 19
dischargeable, domestic support obligation. Debtor’s obligation should have been
determined to be a non-dischargeable, domestic support obligation.
The Bankruptcy Abuse Protection and Consumer Protection Act (“BAPCPA”),
passed by Congress in 2005, made changes to 11 U.S.C. § 523(a)(15), which removed
the balancing test from Section 523(a)(15) and made the distinction between domestic
support obligations and other obligations arising from a divorce immaterial in a
dischargeability analysis. Since the debt owed to a former spouse is not of the kind
described in § 523(a)(5) that is incurred by the debtor in the course of a divorce—i.e.,
distribution of marital property—it is also typically non-dischargeable under 11
U.S.C. § 523(a)(15).
ARGUMENT
I. The bankruptcy court erred to reversal by classifying
Creditor’s Claim Number 19 as a general unsecured
claim because the debt to the Creditor is a non-
dischargeable, domestic support obligation.
Under Chapter 13 bankruptcy, domestic support obligations are non-
dischargeable. In re Benson, 441 Fed.Appx. 650, 651 (11th Cir. 2011) (per curiam);
Cummings v. Cummings, 244 F.3d 1263, 1265 (11th Cir. 2001) (citing 11 U.S.C. §
523(a)(5)). “A domestic support obligation is a debt owed to a former spouse that was
incurred as a result of a [separation agreement, divorce decree, or] property settlement
6
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 6 Filed 11/21/25 Page 13 of 19
agreement that is ‘in the nature of alimony, maintenance, or support ... [of that former
spouse] without regard to whether such debt is expressly so designated.’” Benson,
441 Fed.Appx. at 651 (quoting 11 U.S.C. § 101(14A)) (emphasis in original)
(bracketed material added).
In Edwards v. Colin, 2017 WL 1822570 (M.D. Ala. May 5, 2017), on appeal
by the former wife, the District Court reversed a determination by the Bankruptcy
Court which had held that the property settlement in the parties’ divorce settlement
agreement was dischargeable. The Court found that the Bankruptcy Court erred by
focusing on whether the parties’ settlement could fairly be classified as a property
settlement or as alimony. Id. at *2. In its decision reversing the Bankruptcy Court, the
District Court reasoned that, based on language from the Benson decision, a property
settlement can be a non-dischargeable domestic support obligation. Id. at *3. The
question is whether the award to the Former Wife of half the equity in the marital
residence, even if characterized as a “property settlement,” is in the nature of support.
See Cummings v. Cummings, 244 F.3d at 1265. Here, the evidence shows that the
Former Wife depends on the $2,000 monthly payments to her to meet her financial
obligations.
In Benson, the Eleventh Circuit found that, because of the disparity in the
parties’ financial positions and because the wife waived alimony in consideration of
7
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 6 Filed 11/21/25 Page 14 of 19
the benefits she received in the agreement, the former husband’s mortgage payments
were a non-dischargeable, domestic support obligation. In re Benson, 441 Fed.Appx.
at 651-52. Here, the CS-42 Form, used to calculate the parties’ respective child
support obligations, showed substantial disparity between the parties’ financial
positions with the Former Husband receiving $8,870 monthly and the Former Wife
receiving $1,733 monthly. R. 16, Creditor’s Ex. 2. Further, the divorce court denied
the Former Wife alimony. And the Former Husband’s payments to the Former Wife
were spread over a period of 21 months.
As the Eleventh Circuit found in Cummings [at 1266], an equitable distribution
of assets was a non-dischargeable, domestic support obligation, despite permanent
alimony being denied by the divorce court, and despite the former wife receiving
rehabilitative alimony in addition to the equitable distribution. The Court reasoned
that “[b]ecause a property division often achieves the same goal as a support
obligation, state courts do not rigidly distinguish between the two.” Id. In this case,
alimony was denied but there was no rehabilitative alimony awarded either. Thus,
there is more reason to consider the divorce court’s equitable division of assets in this
case as achieving the same goal as a non-dischargeable, support obligation, just as the
Court did in Cummings. See Edwards v. Colin, 2017 WL 1822570 at * 3 (M.D. Ala.
May 5, 2017) citing In re Gianakas, 917 F.2d 759, 763 (3d Cir. 1990).
8
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 6 Filed 11/21/25 Page 15 of 19
In the Bankruptcy Court’s decision reclassifying Creditor’s claim as a general
unsecured claim, the Court relied on language from the decision in In re Colin, 546
B.R. 455 (Bankr. M.D. Ala. 2016). Doc. 73 at 4. But In re Colin was reversed by
Edwards v. Colin in the District Court. Despite Creditor’s reliance in her brief and
argument on Edwards v. Colin, the Bankruptcy Court did not even refer to that
decision it its order. Further, the Bankruptcy Court did not make any assessment of
whether the divorce court’s equitable division of assets achieves the same goal as a
support obligation. Just as the Bankruptcy Court did in In re Colin, the court below
erred by focusing on whether the parties’ settlement could fairly be classified as a
property settlement or as alimony. Doc. 73 at 6 (“the Court concludes that the
Obligation is not a domestic support obligation, but a property settlement”). The
Bankruptcy Court should have focused on whether the property settlement achieves
the same goal as a support obligation. Edwards v. Colin, 2017 WL 1822570 at * 3
(M.D. Ala. May 5, 2017) citing In re Gianakas, 917 F.2d 759, 763 (3d Cir. 1990).
In this case, it is clear that Debtor’s obligation to Creditor arises from a divorce
decree awarding Creditor half of the equity in the marital residence, or $52,000.00,
since the total payment was not made within 90 days of the entry of the Final Decree
of Divorce. Debtor’s pre-petition payments total $20,000, leaving a balance owing
of $32,000. The divorce court’s division of the parties’ property was a property
9
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 6 Filed 11/21/25 Page 16 of 19
settlement which achieved the same goal as a domestic support obligation. Thus, it
should have been determined to be a non-dischargeable, domestic support obligation.
II. Changes made by BAPCPA further support finding the
divorce court’s equitable distribution of assets a non-
dischargeable, domestic support obligation.
In 2005, Congress passed the Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer
Protection Act (“BAPCPA”). Among the changes enacted was 11 U.S.C. §
523(a)(15), which “removed the balancing test from Section 523(a)(15)2 and made
the distinction between domestic support obligations and other obligations arising
from a divorce immaterial in a dischargeability analysis.” In re Ginzl, 430 B.R. 702,
707 (M.D. Fla. 2010) citing 4 Collier on Bankruptcy, ¶ 523.23, at 523-124 (16th ed.
2009) (footnote added). Accordingly, since the “[d]ebt owed to a former spouse [is]
‘not of the kind described’ in § 523(a)(5) that is ‘incurred by the debtor in the course
2 In pertinent part, 11 U.S.C. § 523(a) provides as follows:
(a) A discharge under section 727, 1141, 11921 1228(a), 1228(b), or 1328(b)
of this title does not discharge an individual debtor from any debt–
* * * * *
(5) for a domestic support obligation;
* * * * *
(15) to a spouse, former spouse, or child of the debtor and not of the kind
described in paragraph (5) that is incurred by the debtor in the course of a divorce or
separation or in connection with a separation agreement, divorce decree or other order
of a court of record, or a determination made in accordance with State or territorial
law by a governmental unit;
10
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 6 Filed 11/21/25 Page 17 of 19
of a divorce’—i.e., distribution of marital property—[it] is also typically non-
dischargeable under 11 U.S.C. § 523(a)(15).” In re Coon, 522 B.R. 357, 361 (M.D.
Ala. 2014) (bracketed material supplied). Because Debtor’s obligation to pay Former
Wife was incurred in the course of the parties’ divorce proceedings and achieves the
same goal as a non-dischargeable, domestic support obligation, Debtor’s obligations
are non-dischargeable pursuant to the plain language of 11 U.S.C. § 523(a)(15) and
Creditor’s claim is entitled to priority under 11 U.S.C. § 507(a)(1)(A).
CONCLUSION
Based on the arguments and authorities cited hereinabove, the Order of the
Bankruptcy Court reclassifying Creditor’s Claim Number 19 as a general unsecured
claim is due to be reversed.
Respectfully submitted this 21st day of November, 2025.
/s/ Algert S. Agricola, Jr.
Attorney for Appellant Brittany Michelle
Gilliland
OF COUNSEL:
Agricola Law, LLC
127 South 8th Street
Opelika, Alabama 36801
334.759.7557 P
334.759.7558 F
al@agricolalaw.com
www.agricolalaw.com
